questions.text: While doing endoscopy, which organ is most likely to be injured at 25 Cm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Arch of aorta

questions.text: Patient present with Halitosis and a swelling in the lateral aspect of neck. Which on pressing gives rise to a regurgitant air sound. Barium image is shown. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Protrusion through Killian’s dehiscence (between Thyropharyngeus and Cricopharyngeus)

•	IOC: Ba Swallow

•	TOC: Diverticulectomy and Cricopharyngomyotomy

•	Dohlmann’s Procedure: Endoscopic procedure

questions.text: A newborn baby on 2nd day of life was found to have continuous frothing of saliva from the mouth in the emergency. He gets choking when he is given milk. X ray image is given below. What is the most likely Diagnosis in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Most common type C (Proximal atresia)

• First test- NGT and X ray (Tube stops at 10 cm from incisor)

• Safest contrast- Iohexol

• Treatment: 

•For fit child- Thoracotomy and ligation of fistula with esophageal anastomosis (Cameron Height operation)

• For low birth weight child + pneumonia- Feeding Gastrostomy and delayed repair

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with 2 episodes of hematemesis. He had a binge of alcohol followed by few episodes of clear vomiting but subsequently he observed blood in vomitus. Endoscopy revealed a longitudinal tear just below GEJ on the right side of cardia with clear base and no active bleeding. What should be best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Observation

questions.text: A middle aged man had an episode of severe vomiting after heavy meal. Since then he is companioning of retrosternal pain. O/E Hamman’s sign is positive and on X ray widening of the mediastinum is seen with pneumo- mediastinum and left pleural effusion. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus

questions.text: A woman brought a 4 weeks old male child to OPD with complaints of recurrent vomiting. USG showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

CONGENITAL HYPERTROPHIC PYLORIC STENOSIS

  • Results in hypertrophy and hyperplasia of Circular muscle.
  • Erythromycin given within 1 week after birth increases the chances of CHPS 
  • Results in gastric outflow obstruction, vomiting and dehydration
  • Affects 3 per 1000 live births
  • Male : female 4:1. Most common in first born males
  • Usually presents between 4 and 6 weeks (3-8) of age
  • Child hungry and often feeds immediately after vomiting
  • Biochemically a Hypochloremic alkalosis exists (with Hypokalemia and paradoxical aciduria)
  • Non-bilious vomiting, associated with weight loss and dehydration, are typical.
  • The upper abdomen may be distended with visible gastric peristalsis (left to right) and a palpable olive shaped lump (hypertrophied pylorus).
  • Features of protein energy malnutrition is absent
  • confirmation of the diagnosis is by ultrasound scanning. – Length of pylorus > 16 mm, width > 4 mm has a accuracy of > 95%. Stomach is empty doesn’t have food residue.
  • First electrolyte imbalance correction is must by – N/2 NS {(.45% saline) with 5% dextrose and Kcl} or RL (RL may increase alkalosis)
  • At laparotomy, pyloromyotomy (Ramstedt's operation) is the usual procedure done through right hypochondrial transverse muscle splitting incision.
  • Atropine is medical management (Not preferred)

questions.text: Identify the surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Nissen fundoplication

questions.text: A child presenting with following x-ray wants is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immediate Endoscopic removal

questions.text: A sigmoid configuration along with tapering beak-like deformity at the lower esophageal sphincter on barium swallow is a feature of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Achalasia Cardia
•    Due to absence of Inhibitory Auerbach’s plexus
•    Secondary achalasia – due to Chagas disease
•    Psudoachalasia: Due to cancer (Cardia > lung)
•    Young age/ Dysphagia - Liquids > solid
•    Increased risk of SCC (In proximal dilated part)
•    X ray- Bird beak sign/ rat tail sign/ sigmoidisation 
•    Manometry – Gold standard (Chicago classification)
•    TOC- Hellers myotomy and Dor (partial fundoplication)
•    POEM (New treatment)

questions.text: Best investigation to look for T and N stage in esophageal carcinoma patients is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Summary IOC: Esophagus • For all anatomical distortion- Barium swallow A. Zenker’s diverticulum: Ba swallow B. Stricture: Barium swallow C. Webs and rings- Barium swallow • All motility disorders (Achalasia/ Nutcracker esophagus/ DES/ Jackhammer esophagus):- Manometry • Achalasia: Ba Swallow (Gold standard - Manometry) • Esophageal perforation: A. To see leak- Barium swallow B. To see inflammation and for Pneumomediastinum- CECT is best • GERD: Gold standard is 24 hrs pH monitoring (De- Meester criteria) • Hiatus hernia Ba Swallow (Now a days CT is being done more commonly)

questions.text: According to the image given below, obtained from the stomach of a woman, which specialist is needed along with surgeon?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Tricobezoar is a psychiatric problem.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with enteric fever presents to the emergency with sudden onset of generalised abdominal pain, abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting and constipation for last 48 hours. On examination, patient is dehydrated with PR= 110/min and BP= 100/60 mm Hg. There is generalized tenderness, rebound tenderness present and board like rigidity on per- abdomen examination. The most likely complication of enteric fever in this patient is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Small bowel perforation

questions.text: A patient who was on NSAID for chronic joint pain came to emergency room with severe diffuse abdominal pain. Pulse 112 beats/ min and SBP 110/80 mmHg mmHg. Chest Xray shown below. During laparotomy a small duodenal perforation was found. What is the best treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Omental patch repair

choices.text: Right gastric artery in gastric ulcer and right gastroepiploic artery in duodenal ulcer
Left gastric artery in gastric ulcer and left gastroepiploic artery in duodenal ulcer
Left gastric artery in gastric ulcer and Gastroduodenal artery in duodenal ulcer
Left gastric artery in gastric ulcer and Pancreaticoduodenal artery in duodenal ulcer

questions.text: Which artery bleeds in gastric and duodenal ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left gastric artery in gastric ulcer and Gastroduodenal artery in duodenal ulcer

questions.text: A patient of adenocarcinoma stomach for which he underwent distal gastrectomy. What should we supplement in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vit B12

questions.text: Following staging is used for which cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The image is of Borrmann classification of gastric cancer

questions.text: Best investigation to detect distant metastasis in gastric cancer is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PET

questions.text: The physician on call is paged to the nursery because a full-term, 3-hour-old boy has had green emesis twice after feeds. He was born by spontaneous vaginal delivery following a pregnancy complicated by polyhydramnios. His upper abdomen is distended. A X-ray done is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 •	Congenital obstruction of the duodenum by a diaphragm or a gap between the two ends of bowel (duodenal atresia). 

 •	The site of obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater so vomiting is of bile-stained (within few hours of birth). 

 •	Its common with Down's syndrome(25-33%) an polyhydroamnios (50%)

 •	X-Ray – Double bubble sign

 •	TOC – Diamond shape duodeno-duodenostomy. (Kimura operation)

choices.text: This structure develops from patent Urachus
Very often ectopic gastric or pancreatic tissue are found in this structure

questions.text: While doing laparotomy the structure shown in the image was incidentally found in the ileum. Which of the following structure is false about this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•Most common congenital anomaly of GIT

• Persistence of the Proximal end of vitelline duct. 

• At the anti- mesenteric border of the ileum 

Rule of 2- 2% incidence, 2 inches long and 2 feet proximal to the ileocaecal valve. 

• It has its own blood supply, independent of ileum (Vitelline artery)

• Ectopic tissue is commonly found in Meckel's diverticulum (gastric > pancreatic).

• Bleeding is the most common presentation (in children) but obstruction (in adults), 

• The best Investigation is technetium-99m pertechnetate scanning. (technetium scan only shows heterotopic gastric mucosa).

• Contrast studies is best in adults (for Meckels without ectopic gastric tissue)

• Meckles without ectopic tissue should be treated by divertculectomy and with ectopic tissue should be treated by R & A

questions.text: A 10-months old infant presents with acute intestinal obstruction. Contrast enema X-ray shows shown below. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Claw sign: Intussusception • Peak incidence age - 6 month- 1 year (Weaning) • Frequently occurs infection Adenovirus type 3 virus (lymphoid hyperplasia that act as “lead point” (of Peyer's patch). • Rota Virus vaccine can also cause intussusception • USG - Target sign, Pseudokidney sign • Ba enema – Claw sign/ Coiled spring sign • Ileocolic – Most common type 70% (in children) • Colocolic – Most common type in adults • Clinical features ➣ Red Currant Jelly tool ➣ Sausage shaped or banana shaped lump ➣ Empty right iliac fossa (Sign of dance) • Treatment: • Reduction with air or contrast enema (>70% success) • Or Surgical manual reduction should be done urgently • Gangrene starts from the apex

questions.text: A 17 years old male was brought to the hospital with recurrent attacks of intussusception. During surgery/multiple polyps/were found in shall intestine. He has pigmentations on the lips One of the polyp was removed, whose histopathological image is given below. What is the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Peutz Jegher syndrome: 

•    AD, Chr 19, gene- STK11/LKB1, Hamartomatous polyp in GIT

•    Pigmentation at muco-cutaneous junction (Lips)

•    GIT cancers- Colon, pancreas, SI, Stomach

•    Breast cancer

•    Lung cancer

•    Sex cord tumor (Sertoli cell tumour/ ovary tumor)

•    Polyps have arborizing pattern of fibro-vascular core (Christmas tree pattern)

questions.text: A 48 year old male presented with complains of pain abdomen, vomiting and off and on diarrhoea. His serum serotonin level is high. Which of the following are the marker for this disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Marker of carcinoid (NET) are 5HIAA and chromogranin A

questions.text: A patient presented with pain left ileac fossa. On examination there was mild tenderness in LIF with a palpable lump. Ba enema picture is given below. What is the diagnosis for this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 ➣    Saw tooth appearance in barium enema

 ➣    Common in old age

 ➣    West > India (high fiber is protective)

 ➣    Involves only colon, Sigmoid is most common site.

 ➣    Presents with bleeding or diverticulitis

 ➣    Most common vessel to bleed in diverticulosis- Branches of SMA

 ➣    Hinchey classification is used for diverticulitis

choices.text: Diverticulitis, do resection and Hartmann’s procedure
Sigmoid volvulus, do resection and anastomosis

questions.text: A 70 year old patient presented with pain abdomen, distention and obstruction for 2 days. X ray image is given below (Pic1). Intraoperative finding is given in picture 2. What is the diagnosis and ideal treatment for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Coffee bean shaped shadow is suggestive of Sigmoid volvulus.

Intraoperative picture is suggestive of gangrene. Gangrenous sigmoid volvulus in emergency is treated by resection and Hartmann’s operation.

questions.text: Management of an appendicular mass in appendicitis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In Acute appendicitis, with delayed treatment in some patients, a appendicular lump forms, which is an inflammatory phlegmon composed of an inflamed appendix, caecum, omentum, terminal ileum, mesoappendix & peritoneum. This usually occurs around 48-72 hours of the onset of first symptoms. As a natural protective mechanism, the omentum & small bowel wrap around the inflamed appendix to isolate it from the rest of the abdominal cavity preventing the spread of infection & forming the components of the lump, usually palpable in the right iliac fossa.
Conventionally Appendicular lump is managed conservatively by Ochsner Sherren regime and after 6-8 weeks an interval appendicectomy is done

questions.text: A30 year old male patient presented with complains of perianal opening with pus discharge. What is most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fistula in Ano

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic constipation. For last 2 days he has severe pain during defecation. He observed a streak of blood by the side of stool. Picture of the lesion is given below. What is the ideal treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

This is a case of acute fissure in Ano. Best surgical treatment for fissure in Ano is internal sphincterotomy.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the OPD with an abdominal lump in the periumbilical region which moves at the right angles to the attachment of mesentery. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chylolymphatic Mesenteric cyst

questions.text: A Chronic alcoholic patient with chronic liver disease presents with hematemesis. He has a report of UGI endoscopy done few weeks back. The image of endoscopy given below. Which of the following treatment is not included in immediate treatment of hematemesis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Beta blocker in esophageal varices in used for prophylaxis, not in acute variceal bleed.

questions.text: What is the Gharbi grade of the Hydatid cyst image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gharbi 2

questions.text: 25 year old patient presents with fever and slight weight loss. He gives a history of blood in stools and dairrhoea few weeks back. On examination, there is right hypochondrial pain and hepatomegaly. USG and CT Images of liver is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Amoebic liver abscess

choices.text: Hepatitis B and C are main cause of HCC
CEA is the main tumor marker.
Surgery is the TOC as the response of Chemo and radiotherapy is poor
Triple phase CT scan is IOC

questions.text: Which of the following is false about HCC?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tumour marker for HCC is AFP not CEA

questions.text: A 32 year old lady underwent USG abdomen which showed incidental following finding, Her LFT reports are normal. What is be best advice for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Treatment of asymptomatic gall stone is observation. Indications of cholecystectomy in asymptomatic patient are:

➣	Size of stone: > 3 cm

➣	Associated conditions: Immunocompromised, pregnancy, DM?

➣	Polyp: > 1cm

➣	Hemolytic anaemia

➣	Bariatric surgery (BPD/ Duodenal switch)

➣	Prolonged octreotide therapy

➣	Typhoid carrier

➣	Porcelain GB

choices.text: Conservative management and interval cholecystectomy after 6 weeks
MRCP to rule out CBD stone followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy

questions.text: A 50 year old lady presented with pain right upper abdomen for 1 day. USG image showed multiple gall stone. CBD on USG is of normal calibre and LFT is normal. What should be the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy

choices.text: CBD exploration and T Tube insertion
ERCP and decompression of CBD followed by 2nd stage cholecystectomy
ERCP and decompression of CBD with immediate cholecystectomy

questions.text: What is the ideal management of Raynauld’s pentad?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ERCP and decompression of CBD followed by 2nd stage cholecystectomy

questions.text: Rigler’s triad is found in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gallstone ileus is a rare condition where Gall bladder develops s fistula with duodenum. Then a stone passed in SI through the fistula and gets trapped in distal ileum of ileo-caecal junction causing intestinal obstruction.

choices.text: Conservative treatment with coverage of gram-negative bacteria
CBE exploration and T Tube insertion

questions.text: A 50 year old female, known diabetic with controlled blood sugar, presented with right upper abdominal pain and fever. O/E her BP is 105/70 and PR is 102/ min. Murphey’s sign is positive. CT picture is given below. What is the diagnosis and best treatment for her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is a case of emphysematous cholecystitis suggested by presence of air in gall bladder. Mainly seen in diabetic/ immunocompromised patients. Main pathogen is clostridia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and jaundice. Subsequent “MRCP” reveals a cystic anomaly of her biliary system illustrated in the film below. What is the diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Choledochal cyst

Congenital Cystic dilatation of Bile duct

 ➣    F > M

 ➣    1: 50,000 - 1,00,000

 ➣    ABPJ suspected as aetiology

 ➣    Presentation. 

 ➣    Jaundice is the most consistent symptom, 

 ➣    Right upper quadrant pain and rarely a palpable mass. 

 ➣    nonspecific problems- weight loss, nausea, and vomiting, Fever.

 ➣    Rish factor for CBD and GB cancer

 ➣    Treated by excision of cyst with Roux en Y hepatico jejunostomy

questions.text: According to Bismuth classification, which of the Following is type Ill bile duct stricture?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A 40 year old patient presented in emergency after binge drinking overnight and sever pain in abdomen. Pain in radiating to the back. Serum Lipase and Amylase is high, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A patient 4 weeks after recovering from acute pancreatitis come with complains of upper abdominal mild pain, fullness, early satiety. On examination a vague epigastric lump is palpable. CT image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pseudo pancreatic cyst

Pseudo pancreatic cyst

1: It is a collection of fluid around pancreas which develops a reactionary fibrous wall (> 4 weeks).

2: Most common site is lesser sac but may be found anywhere in  retroperitoneum or even in mediastinum or inguinal canal.

3: It does not have epithelial lining. Its has a capsule of Collagen and granulation tissue

4: Causes: Chronic pancreatitis > Acute pancreatitis > trauma (In children Trauma is the most common cause Q)

5: Cyst fluid – High Amylase high with low mucin and CEA (Mucinous cystadenoma has high Mucin and CEA)

6: Most common complication is infection (other complications are Haemorrhage; Obstruction of Duodenum, CBD or GOO; Rupture)

7: Surgery is only done for size of > 6 cm after 6 weeks (normally 8-12 weeks). We wait for 6 week for maturity of wall.

8: Preferred surgery is cystogastrostomy but if the cyst is located below transverse mesocolon then cysto- Jejunostomy should be done

questions.text: Most common complication of ERCP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pancreatitis

questions.text: The sign shown in the image is least likely to be caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The picture shows Grey Turner sin and Cullens sign which are suggestive of retroperitoneal hemorrhage. These signs are commonly seen in Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis, but may be seen in other causes of hemorrhage like ruptured ectopic pregnancy, rupture of aortic aneurysm or seat belt injury. 

This sign is not seen in pancreatic cancer

questions.text: Name the operation shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The picture is showing Whipple’s operation which is done for pancreatic (Head) cancer. In Whipple’s pancreatico-duodenectomy is done.

questions.text: Treatment of insulinoma less than 2 cm in size in the head of pancreas is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Insulinoma are encapsulated. Insulinoma of < 2 cm in size are considered benign therefore they are treated by enucleation. 
Insulinoma of > 2cm in size are considered malignant and are treated by Whipple’s operation

questions.text: Endocrine tumour of pancreas associated with DM and dermatitis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

➣    Glucagonoma is associated with DM, Dermatitis and DVT with Anaemia and stomatitis. 

➣    Dermatitis of Glucagonoma is called “Necrolytic migratory erythema”.

questions.text: Elderly male on DRE was found to have a rectal mass on regular check-up, raising the suspicion of rectal cancer. He gives H/O occasional bleeding PR for last few weeks. Which of the following should be recommended as the next step to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Full colonoscopy and biopsy

questions.text: A homosexual man presented with painful defecation and foul smelling lump at anal verge which is not reducible manually. On examination cauliflower-like mass was found which on Biopsy was proved to be squamous cell carcinoma of the anal verge. What will be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SCC of anal canal is treated by Chemo- radiotherapy called “Nigro regimen”.

questions.text: Commonest hernia in female?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Although femoral hernia is four times more common in females yet in both sexes more common hernia is indirect inguinal hernia.

questions.text: While operating on a case of inguinal hernia in 65 years old male, surgeon found the sac located medial to inferior epigastric artery. Best surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	If the sac is media to inferior epigastric artery than it is a direct hernia (In indirect hernia the sac in lateral to inf epigastric artery). 

•	For indirect or direct inguinal hernia best treatment is hernioplasty (Lichtenstein repair).

questions.text: A 40-years-old man complains of loss of sensation over the right scrotum and on the medial right thigh. Damage to which of the following nerves would result in such symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ilioinguinal

choices.text: IVP may show maiden waist deformity
Associated PUJ obstruction is very often found with this condition

questions.text: A patient presented in the OPD with hematuria. He has been suffering from recurrent episodes of urinary tract infection. CT scan image is given below. Which of the following is wrong about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Maiden waist deformity is seen in Retro-peritoneal fibrosis.

•	The 'horseshoe kidney' is the most common renal fusion anomaly

•	M > F

•	The isthmus lies against L4 because ascent is tethered by inf mesenteric artery. 

•	Isthmus causes kink at PUJ causing obstruction.

•	IVP shows medially direct lower most calyx in horse-shoe kidney.

•	Prophylactic isthmectomy has no role

questions.text: A 5 year old girl presented with continuous dribbling but she is having normal voiding also. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ectopic ureter

questions.text: A 42 year old female with long history of poorly controlled diabetes presented with right flank pain, fever with chills and dysuria. Blood test showed elevated counts and blood culture was positive. Urine examination revealed full field of WBC. CT scan picture is given below. What is the most common pathogen responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This is a case of emphysematous pyelonephritis (Suggested by air inside the kidney). emphysematous pyelonephritis is common in daibetics and is caused by E coli.

questions.text: A young child was found to have a lump in left flank. USG showed left hydronephrosis with dilated calyx and pelvis but collapsed ureter. Radiology images are given below. DTPA scan showed a function 30%. Bets treatment for this child is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Procedures for PUJ obstruction:

•    Anderson-Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty (Most commonly done surgery with best results).

choices.text: X ray of Polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: Identify the investigation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: What instrument is used to insert this tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cystoscope

choices.text: Radical nephrectomy with removal of ureter till pelvic brim
Radical nephrectomy with removal of ureter till bladder

questions.text: A 27 year old patient presented with a renal mass at lower pole with size 7 × 5 × 4 cm. Urinary cytology revealed adenocarcinoma. CT scan-based staging is, T-1B N0 M0. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 •	Radical nephrectomy is the treatment for renal cell cancer

 •	In radical nephrectomy, Kidney is removed along with intact Gerota’s fascia therefore perirenal 
fat and abdominal ureter (till pelvic brim/ bifurcation of common iliac) is also removed.

 •	Adrenal is also removed in some cases. Node removal has no beneficial role on survival.

 •	Partial nephrectomy is done for tumour size < 4 cm (or in some cases up to 7 cm) in solitary functioning kidney or B/L tumours.

choices.text: This stone forms in alkaline urine
PCNL is the treatment of choice
Usually composed of Magnesium ammonium phospahate.

questions.text: A patient presented with chronic pain in left flank. X ray and CT image given below. Which statement is false about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 •    This is a staghorn calculus which is made up of triple phosphate (Struvite). It forms in Alkaline urine and is best treated by PCNL. Its crystals are coffin lid shaped.

 •    Hexagonal crystals are cystine stone crystals

choices.text: Treatment is chemotherapy followed by Surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Nephroblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wilms tumor/ Nephroblastoma
•	It is common in children < 6 years of life (usually after 2 years)
•	Develops from blastemal tissue (Nephrogenic rests)
•	Higher risk is WAGR syndrome, Danys Drash syndrome and Beckwith Wiedemann syndrome.
•	Most common presentation Abdominal lump (does not cross midline)
•	Node metastasis are rare. Blood born secondary to lung is common.
•	NWTS and SIOP staging is used
•	Treated by Surgery (with chemo and radiotherapy).

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient with lower urinary tract symptom for 2 years was evaluated for lower urinary tract symptoms. Ultrasound revealed a 40 grams prostate with 50 ml of residual urine. PSA is 1.2 ngm/ml. He was diagnosed as a case of BPH. What is the best next step for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Investigations: USG is the investigation of choice. PSA (prostate specific antigen) is helpful in excluding carcinoma. Its normal value is 0- 4 ng/dl. 

Normal weight and size of prostate is 20 gms and 20 cc.

For this patient initial treatment should be medical management (Alpha 1a blocker with 5 HT inhibitor).

choices.text: Osteoblastic secondaries to bones (vertebra) are common
Gleason score is used for grade

questions.text: Which of the following is false about carcinoma prostate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Chemotherapy response to Prostate cancers is very poor.

choices.text: Neoadjuvant Chemoradiotherapy followed by Radical cystectomy
Transurethral resection of bladder tumour followed by intravesical BCG.

questions.text: TCC of bladder invading muscle is treated by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Management of bladder cancer:
1: Non muscle-invasive bladder cancer (Ta, T1, CIS)

First step - transurethral resection of bladder tumor (TURBT).

  • Small-volume, low-grade Ta bladder cancer – Regular follow up or a postoperative single dose of intravesical chemotherapy
  • High-risk Ta, T1, and CIS urothelial carcinoma - Intravesical BCG/ Chemotherapy

2: The treatment of muscle-invasive bladder cancer:

  • Radical cysto-prostatectomy in men and Radical cystectomy with anterior pelvic exenteration in women with bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy (PLND)
  • Followed by neoadjuvant chemotherapy (MVAC)

questions.text: During cystoscopic examination the scope moves freely, MCU shown below. Management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior urethral valve

•    M/C case of male neonate bladder outlet obstruction 

•    Membrane like fold below Veru- montanum.

•    Type 1 is most common

•    Cause back pressure – Megabladder, Megaureter and sever VUR

•    In severe cases patient may have Oligohydramnios, Renal hypoplasia and pulmonary hypoplasia and Urinary ascites.

•    IOC- MCU (VCUG), USG (Key hole sign)

•    TOC: Endoscopic fulguration

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in photo?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bladder extropy

questions.text: A 14 years old boy is presented with absent left testis in scrotum. On examination, left testis was Found in superior inguinal pouch. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ectopic testis

questions.text: A 35 years old male came to OPD with swelling in left scrotal region and pain, Pain increased on standing and in the evening. On palpation, it feels tike bag of worms. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    Varicocele is dilatation of pampiniform plexus in spermatic cord

•    A varicocele may develop as a result of poorly functioning valves that are normally found in veins. 
In other cases, it may occur from the compression of a vein by a nearby structure.

•    L>R
•    Varicoceles can cause problems with fertility, decreased sperm count, and abnormal sperm morphology.
•    O/E gives bag of worm feel
•    IOC- Colour doppler
•    Treated by angio-embolization, Varicocelectomy and Palomo operation
•    The 5 signs of a varicocele, include a scrotal mass, heavy sensation, enlarged veins, dull or sharp pain, and infertility issues.

choices.text: USG to rule out obstructed hernia
Doppler to rule out Testicular torsion
USG to rule out undescended testsi

questions.text: 18 year old boy with sudden onset of pain in right inguino-scrotal area with redness and swelling in scrotum. O/E right side cremasteric reflex is absent and right testis is pulled up. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Testicular torsion
•	Common in teenage
•	M/C type: Intravaginal
•	High invagination of tunica vaginalis (Clapper bell deformity)
•	Pain inguino-scrotal area
•	Pulled up testis
•	Loss of cremasteric reflex
•	Prehn Sign
•	Deming Sign
•	Angel Sign
•	IOC- Doppler
•	Immediate exploration and B/L fixation

choices.text: Schiller Duval bodies may be found
May present as precocious puberty in children
If this is malignant type then radiotherapy has no role in the treatment of these tumours

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasonography (USG) reveals a 1-cm solid mass within the body of the testis. His serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the false statement about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

➣	This is Leydig cell tumour which produces testosterone and presents with precocious puberty

➣	Inclusion body of Leydig cell is Reinke crystals

choices.text: Treatment is to provide scrotal support
Treatment is to wait and watch
Testis are preserved in this pathology

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathology shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fournier’s Gangrene
•	This is a synergistic infection.
•	(Combined Anerobic and Aerobic infection)
•	Rapidly progressing infection Involving scrotum and perineal skin
•	Testis is never involved due to tunica albuginea barrier 
•	Broad spectrum antibiotics with debridement is main stay of treatment
•	(Surgery- Shameless exposure of testis)

questions.text: Which of the following should be used for pre-operative management in a patient with pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Pheochromocytoma are tumors of adrenal medulla. They produce catecholamines (epinephrine and nor-epinephrine).

•	Treatment with alpha- and beta-blockers is required preoperatively to control BP and prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises. 

•	Start alpha blockade with phenoxybenzamine 7-10 days preoperatively.

•	Initiate a beta-blocker only after adequate alpha blockade. If beta blockade is started prematurely, unopposed alpha stimulation can precipitate a hypertensive crisis.

•	Administer the last doses of oral alpha- and beta-blockers on the morning of surgery

questions.text: Identify the condition based on the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Adder head or cobra head appearance of ureterocoele

questions.text: What is the name of this investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Retrograde urethrogram

questions.text: A patient presented to hospital with increased frequency of micturition. On cystoscopy, pale ureteric orifice was seen. MRI image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thimble bladder is a feature of TB of bladder

questions.text: A 50 year old patient presented with ascites, pain and tenderness over abdomen. Ascitic fluid showed presence of 600 WBC/ Cmm and 350 Neutrophils/ cmm. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dx- Primary spontaneous bacterial peritonitis
